bibl.title: Alexandria in Aegypto. The Use and Meaning of Egyptian Elements in Hellenistic and Roman Alexandria.
bibl.note: Introduction. - The Available Data: 1. Egyptian Elements in Early Hellenistic Greco-Alexandrian Tombs; Shatby Hypogaeum A and Mustapha Pasha I; - 2. Egyptian Elements in Early Hellenistic Monumental Art and Architecture: The Sarapeion; - 3. Egyptian Elements in Late Hellenistic Funerary Customs; - 4. Egyptian Elements in Other Domains of Late Hellenistic Alexandria; - 5. Egyptian Elements in Roman Alexandria. - Conclusion. - P. 86: Addendum: New evidence concerning the use of Aegyptiaca in Alexandria.

bibl.title: Isis on the Nile. Egyptian Gods in Hellenistic and Roman Egypt. Proceedings of the IVth International Conference of Isis Studies, Liège, November 27-29, 2008. Michel Malaise in honorem

bibl.seg: SAVVOPOULOS Kyriakos, Alexandria in Aegypto. The Use and Meaning of Egyptian Elements in Hellenistic and Roman Alexandria.

Laurent BRICAULT and Miguel John VERSLUYS (Edd.), Isis on the Nile. Egyptian Gods in Hellenistic and Roman Egypt. Proceedings of the IVth International Conference of Isis Studies, Liège, November 27-29, 2008. Michel Malaise in honorem = Religions in the Graeco-Roman World. 171 (Leiden, 2010) pp. 75-86 et 9 figg.

Introduction. - The Available Data: 1. Egyptian Elements in Early Hellenistic Greco-Alexandrian Tombs; Shatby Hypogaeum A and Mustapha Pasha I; - 2. Egyptian Elements in Early Hellenistic Monumental Art and Architecture: The Sarapeion; - 3. Egyptian Elements in Late Hellenistic Funerary Customs; - 4. Egyptian Elements in Other Domains of Late Hellenistic Alexandria; - 5. Egyptian Elements in Roman Alexandria. - Conclusion. - P. 86: Addendum: New evidence concerning the use of Aegyptiaca in Alexandria.
